III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
The facility was converted from a duplex to a six-bedroom residential facility that
includes a full NFPA 13D sprinkler system and fire alarm system. The facility is
located in the community in a residential neighborhood. The facility has a fenced in
backyard and the garage and driveway are located at the rear of the facility. As you
enter the front door of the facility, there is a small foyer with a half bathroom located
to the left. Walking through the foyer to the left is a small hallway that includes two
single bedrooms including a twin-size bed, dresser and closet. Also located in the
hallway is a full bathroom with a standing shower. Walking through the foyer to the
2

right is a longer hallway that includes four bedrooms including a twin-size bed,
dresser and closet. There is walk through full bathroom with a shower/tub that can
be assessed through the hallways or dining room area. At the end of the hallway is a
linen closet, where the facility stores cleaning supplies. As you walk through the
foyer area, there is an open space including two tables and eight chairs for a dining
room. To the left of the dining area is a full kitchen that includes all major appliances
that were observed to be in working order. The kitchen has an external door that
leads outside to the parking area. To the right of the dining area is access to the full
bathroom with a shower/tub that was mentioned above. Leaving the dining room
area, there is a staircase to the right leading to the basement. Immediately ahead of
the dining room is a living room area that includes two couches and four chairs.
There is a door leading outside that is adjacent to the kitchen outside door. The
living room also has sliding glass doors that leads to a fenced in backyard with a
shallow deck. There is one room located off the living room which the facility plans to
use as their medication and health room. This room includes cabinets and a table.
The door locks and the facility will have locked tackle boxes to store medication
within the cabinets. There is also a door leading to the garage off the living room.
The garage is a one stall garage that includes a locked utility closet.
Off the dining room, the staircase leads to the basement. At the bottom of the stairs
you turn right to enter a large hallway. To the right is a large locked utility closet. To
the left is a laundry room including a washer and dryer, as well as an additional
refrigerator. At the end of the hallway, is a large open room with glass block
windows. To the left is a doorway leading to a staff office that includes multiple
desks and cabinets as well as glass block windows. To the right is a door in the
concrete cylinder block wall, that leads into another large open room with glass block
windows. The facility plans to utilize this area for indoor recreation. As you enter
this room to the right is another doorway that leads to a smaller open room. This
area has an egress window. It has two utility closets located on opposite sides of
the room that are locked.
B. Program Description
The Elaine Avenue program of the Great Lakes Center for Autism Treatment and
Research (GLC-EA) is a community-based, unsecured, residential program for up to
six youth who have a primary diagnosis of Autism and/or other closely related
intellectual developmental disability. Youth admitted will be between 7 years and 17
years of age, whom have previously displayed high levels of challenging behavior
which has been successfully treated, and whom require continued intervention or
who are wards of the state of Michigan and are unable to be served in a foster care
home. Referral sources for children may come from a variety of sources and funders
including Community Mental Health Organizations, Department of Health and
Human Services and/or private insurance.
The GLC-EA will provide at minimum the following services to youth admitted to the
program: Oversight of behavioral treatment by a Board Certified Behavioral
Analyst(BCBA) , the provision of a reasonable amount of materials necessary to
3

implement the behavior service plan, behavioral treatment implemented by direct
care staff and overseen by a BCBA, the review the behavior treatment plan by Great
Lake Center’s behavior consultation committee (BCC) no fewer than 4 times
annually, the provision of room and board, the provision of daily activities, the
provision of reasonable assistance in the completion of all necessary activities of
daily living as identified in the youth’s service plan, the level of reasonable
assistance necessary in personal care tasks as identified in the individual service
plan, participation as required in service planning and family team meetings,
participation as required in court hearings related to the abuse or neglect of a child
served, the dispensing of oral medications as prescribed by a physician,
transportation to and from medical appointments located within Kalamazoo county, a
bi-annual review of medical care by a registered nurse, one psychological evaluation
during the course of treatment for DHHS youth only, provision of parent and/or
caregiver training opportunities prior to a planned discharge, and any other services
agreed to within the individual plan of service or otherwise guaranteed through Great
Lake Center’s policy, Residential Opportunities, Inc policy, or required by the
Division of Child Welfare Licensing.
The Assessment of Functional Living Skills (AFLS) shall be used as the
standardized assessment tool for the assessment of communication and other
adaptive skills. The Child Assessment of Needs and Strengths (CANS) assessment
will be used as the standardized assessment for assessing a youth’s behavioral and
educational barriers to being placed in a less restrictive setting. A youth will be
assessed using the AFLS assessment within 30 days of admission and twice
annually thereafter. Prior to each service plan meeting (occurring minimally every 90
days) the educational and permanency specialist, will conduct a records review and
affirm that the assessment results remain valid. If there is reason to believe that the
results are not valid a youth will participate in an additional assessment within 30
days. Other events and activities in the community may be provided consistent with
the service plan of the individual and the funding source.
GLC-EA may provide, through contractual agreement with Western Michigan
University School of Medicine, the provision of basic psychiatric services, including:
Regular medicine reviews, basic assessment at admission, and provision of
recommendations prior to a planned discharge. Should GLC-EA not do so GLC-EA
will instead help arrange for, transport to, and participate in psychiatric appointments
being funded by Medicaid and/or private funding.
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
The facility is in compliance with all rules and statutes.
4

It is recommended an original license be issued to this private child caring
